thread.title: Uber responds to labor commissioner, says drivers are independent contractors
thread.title_full: Uber responds to labor commissioner, says drivers are independent contractors

author: Elliot Njus | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: Uber responds to labor commissioner, says drivers are independent contractors
text:
Uber fired off a response to Oregon Labor Commissioner Brad Avakian on Tuesday following his assertion last week that the company's drivers are employees , not independent contractors. 
Avakian wrote in an advisory opinion last week that because Uber drivers are employees, the company should be responsible for employment taxes, minimum wage and workers' compensation insurance. 
In its response Tuesday, Uber regional general manager William Barnes said the opinion is "filled with factual errors and assertions that are simply wrong." 
Barnes argues that most of Uber's drivers work less than 10 hours a week, and that many also use competing platforms like Lyft to find more rides. 
And citing an internal survey, Barnes said drivers value the freedom to work on their own terms, and that 87 percent said they "want to be their own boss." 
Uber drivers provide on-demand rides to customers who request them through Uber's app. Uber sets the rates and collects payments, taking a portion as its fee. Drivers use their own vehicles and set their own hours. They can be booted from the platform if too many riders give them low ratings. 
Avakian argued Uber drivers fit the state's definition of employees because they work for the company's benefit and they're economically dependent on the ride-hailing company. 
The opinion wasn't prompted by any particular case, and it doesn't carry the legal force of an order or a ruling. But it signaled that bureau would likely rule against Uber if a case were brought against the company. 
-- Elliot Njus
